page.title: 18MINK HUNTING, BERKELEY PILL
page.content: {Mink}which have either{escaped}from fur farms or been{'liberated'}by animal rights activists are regarded by conservationists as a{threat to {existing wildlife,}esp. kingfishers. Farmers are{officially}encouraged to kill off all mink. Some local people join a{hunt}organised by a 'Master' which uses a pack of about{30 hounds (usually the ones unfit for fox hunting). The day begins at the Salutation Inn in nearby Ham, from where the party sets off down the Pill. The hounds begin searching the undergrowth for a mink; once found, it is{chased}up the Pill until the hounds catch it and{chew it up.}The mink's death is supposed to be quick! A hunt can last all day and the amount of mink killed varies. At the end of the day the loyal supporters return to the Inn for a{celebratory drink.
